movieReview: I've never been a huge fan of this movie, but it had been ages since I'd seen it and the fam wanted to watch it.  I still think it's not that great.

I wasn't expecting much from this movie, but it delivered an enjoyable-enough rental/cable flick.  It's super OK, nothing great, and has plot holes for days, but if you are just looking for a dumb B movie it'll fit the bill.

The first 30 minutes of this were laughably (but not enjoyably) bad.  Once Eddie met Venom it got more fun, but in a C-movie kind of way.  It's basically impossible for me to really recommend this in any real way, but once it got rolling it was watchable.
This was a very beautiful film with some great performances.  The two leads were wonderful.  There are some minor quibbles I could make with the editing and pacing, but overall it was very good.
I had seen this before, but I thought it might be a good idea to revisit before seeing SPLIT.  It was pretty good, perhaps better than I remember.

I had avoided this for awhile after swearing off M. Night years ago.  But I had head so many positive reviews of this movie I eventually relented.  Happy to say that it was pretty alright!  Not great, but a fun small movie.  I don't have a ton of confidence he won't fuck it up with GLASS, though.
Everyone keeps telling me that the Harry Potter movies get better as you go on, and I started to believe that with 3, but this one was atrocious.
movieTitle: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire

movieReview: Ok, phew, after the terrible fourth movie this one was at least entertaining.
movieTitle: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

movieReview: I was curious about the wraparound footage they shot.  Overall the movie still is OK, they did some funny thing with the PG-13ness of it, but generally it was a lesser version.  The Fred Savage stuff was a fun addition though.
This was not the movie I was expecting, but I liked it.  It felt marketed more in line with something like 'Seven Psychopaths', but wasn't particularly funny (nor trying to be).
movieTitle: Bad Times at the El Royale

movieReview: Hulu's doc focused more on some of the people who worked the festival telling their stories as well as an interview with Billy McFarland, the now-felon who organized the festival.  Interesting, but felt real thin in places.  Too many interviews with/about the "social media influencers" that promoted and got swindled by this nonsense.
This was the better of the two Fyre Festival documentaries.
A solid retrospective on the 2018 World Series as produced by MLB.  Pretty standard fare, but enjoyable for a fan.
movieTitle: 2018 World Series Champions: Boston Red Sox

movieReview: This took a bit to get going but it won me over by the end.

Woofa-goofa was this a stinker.  C-level fan service, ridiculous yet boring plot, no explanation for Olivia Munn's proficiency with both science and firearms.  If you're going to have a scientist-action hero, that's fine, but give us some indication of why this bookworm is also a badass.
I couldn't sleep on my flight to Edinburgh and needed something I'd already seen but that didn't suck.  Black Panther fit the bill 100
I saw most of this show when I saw Henry a year or two ago in Rhode Island, but I always enjoy seeing him.  I'm glad he was able to do another special.

I had been wanting to watch this again, and lucky for me it was available on my flight to Puerto Rico.  That said, watching it on the tiny JetBlue seat-back screen was less than ideal.  Still a pretty good biopic.
I've wanted to re-watch this for years now, and I finally did after reading an oral history of the film.  Today is the 20th anniversary of its release.  Still great.
This was a good movie, but it wasn't fun.  Jonas Åkerlund definitely got the mood right, and I wish he would direct more films.
I didn't like this movie.  Misery porn until the last 5 minutes, then a stupid tacked on improbable happy ending.
Needed to watch this again after listening to a podcast about Apollo 13
A nice profile of an actor who I only really knew via John Waters.

This was not a good movie, but it was much better than most of the other DC films (Wonder Woman not included).  It was super goofy, had actual fun moments, and a color palette.  But it was a bit TOO goofy and had a pretty thin plot.

This was the first Marvel movie I truly enjoyed in awhile.  The stakes (while still "planets at war") felt smaller, with only a few dozen actual 'warriors' in the film.  Brie Larson really brought something fresh to the 'origin story trope', having a certain amount of self-assuredness right out of the gate.
I guess I lost track of THE GAUNTLET, but this was a great finale.
A good, old look at the special effects of the Star Wars, Indiana Jones and 2010 films.  Restored by Harmy.
As always, Alex Gibney does a great job of presenting this story.
movieTitle: The Inventor: Out for Blood in Silicon Valley

movieReview: Great profile of The Satanic Temple, fighting the good fight for secular government.
Wow, what a story!
Watched this at work as part of a social event.  It'd been awhile since seeing it last and it's still pretty hilariously stupid.

Finally had the opportunity to see the Wax Trax! doc INDUSTRIAL ACCIDENT tonight at #BUFF2019.  It was so nice to learn about the couple (as well as the rest of the staff) behind one of the labels that completely redirected my tastes.
movieTitle: Industrial Accident: The Story of Wax Trax! Records

movieReview: This was very interesting, but some of the digital restoration magic was a bit too 'uncanny valley' for me.
Watched this again after the news story about India blowing up a satellite and creating a debris field.  Still good.
This was a bit stretched, but I do love Creepshow.
This was a movie..  It wasn't bad, but it didn't have much going for it.
Very good, though I wish they explained the 'technical issues' that prevented it from being originally released a bit more..  One extra expository "slide" at the beginning would be good enough.
You'd think a documentary about a single scene in a film would be boring, but not when A) it's one of the greatest films of all time and B) covers a bit more than the one scene of that film.
I had forgotten about this story, but it came across HBO Now so I gave it a watch...  It was an OK doc, but definitely was stretched a bit.  I feel for all families involved.
movieTitle: There's Something Wrong with Aunt Diane

movieReview: LUCE was a great film that will leave you uncomfortable and doesn't give you all the answers. In this film, as in life, leaders are complicated.
A nice little doc short about a cobbler in Waltham, MA...  Interesting subject and well edited, not a lot of fat.
movieTitle: The Best Way Is By Hand

movieReview: This one was all about it's subject matter...  It kept moving and surprising, which isn't easy for a short.

I wanted to like this short doc about a Buddhist who has been "On Retreat" for decades, but it missed explaining some fundamental things (like what Retreat meant for the subject)..  Perhaps that was by design, but it was frustrating.
I did not like this short.  It felt like the director happened to be on a cruise and stole a bunch of shots.  The composition of the shots was good, but overall it seemed adrift.
This was fine, but it also felt like I'd seen a version of this before.  It also didn't really say much about how the Success Academy is different from other schools, charter or otherwise.
I enjoyed this a bunch.  Great performances from the always-reliable Olivia Colman and Walton Goggins, but I also enjoyed the performances from younger actors Alice Englert and Kaitlyn Dever.
This was tons of fun...  Somewhat straightforward "stupid criminals" fare with a very non-straightforward way about it.

This was an interesting look into the evolving world of the used video game store and how it is being impacted by the move to digital distribution.  Other than perhaps feeling a tad long, it was well edited and had great subjects.
A look into a better way for police to interact with citizens in mental health crises. I hope PDs and other first responders across the country will consider these tactics.

THE GOOD, THE BAD, THE HUNGRY was a doc profiling the rise of Kobayashi, Chestnut and Major League Eating. Was either the best or worst choice after an enormous breakfast at The Neighborhood and before dinner at Redbones
movieTitle: The Good, The Bad, The Hungry

movieReview: This was compelling, frustrating, and informative.  The government of Mexico City is clearly not only neglecting its citizens, but also making life extra hard for those trying to help.
This was one of the best docs I've seen in awhile.  It had me on the edge of my seat, laughing, shaking my head in disbelief and questioning my own sanity.  A fascinating film.
This was a heavy way to start the morning, but I'm glad I got to see it. The One Child Policy in China was always fully abstract to me. No longer.

I was dozing off on occasion during this (more a fault of it being in the middle of the festival and less an indictment of the film) so it's hard to give it a fair shake.  It was a good documentary on an interesting subject.
This was fascinating, and would make a great double-feature with last night's AMAZING JOHNATHAN DOCUMENTARY.  Loved it.

I was afraid that this would be a sycophantic love letter but it was much more even handed than I feared. Similar in style to LOS ANGELES PLAYS ITSELF and ROOM 237, with audio interviews over existing footage, it was well paced and edited.  The choice to not interview creatives involved with the film was good.
This was a great profile of a 90 year old firecracker.  It was very interesting in learning about her life and career, as she's been someone who's seemingly always existed during my life.
This was a fun, local film that kept moving and riffed on horror-comedy in a fun way.  I also appreciated that it was on the shorter side;  Not all movies need to be 90-120-240 minutes...
This was a great short, tight and told a clear story.  The ending really made it.
I love Robin Wiegert and there were some moments in this short, but it really never added up to anything.
This is more or less all based on a "monologue", which is wonderful and the lead's performance is great.
This was a solid short about the struggle of deciding when it is the right time to put a loved one in special care housing.
This really reminded me of some of my time working computer retail.  A moving short and a nice story.
This was compelling and weird, not for everyone but it worked for me.
This was hilarious, awkward and moved along well.  This will either be a cult favorite or one of those breakthrough weird comedies that breaks big.
This was a solid film, and a fitting way to say farewell to #IFFBoston
I had forgotten I backed this crowdfunding campaign years ago and received this in the mail the other day.  What a pleasant surprise!  A little disjointed at times, but so is Negativland.
movieTitle: Media About Media About Media: The Negativland Story

movieReview: This was entertaining.  At least it was an actual movie instead of the 2.5h post-credits scene of INFINITY WAR.  It was far too long and the big fight climax was muddy and suffered from the swarm of faceless enemies that has far too long been the Marvel go-to.  I really hope that Marvel takes this opportunity to A) keep the cast list and stakes lower in future team-ups and 2) stops the scourge of post-credit scenes.
A fun, cyberpunk b-movie that was surprisingly solid.
This was fine...  Seth Rogen is way too schlubby for me to accept that he'd get Charlize, but whatever.  It had some very funny moments and was fine the rest of the time.
I hadn't seen this since it was in the theatre.  It was better than I remembered, though it still suffers from showing more of the world that was only hinted at in the first.
This was great.  Still not as special as the first, but super well done and enjoyable.
Still so awesome.  Looks amazing in 4K HDR.
This was a mediocre biopic that certainly glossed over some ugly details.
I know I just saw this a week ago, but I needed to see it again.  If they can keep the quality in the realm of these 3 films I'll take John Wick films until the heat death of the universe.
I shouldn't have let M. Night trick me again....   Split was clearly a fluke, because this was super boring.
A surprising documentary featuring Keanu Reeves interviewing Directors, Cinematographers, Colorists, etc about the Film to Digital transition.
It was hard for me to shift gears back into Deadwood after so long away, but this was a fine quasi-conclusion for a show that never got the finale it deserved.
This was fine, but I wish it was also able to go beyond the creation of the final season and cover some of the controversy of it.
movieTitle: Game of Thrones: The Last Watch

movieReview: A nice version of the "senior-year nerds learn to party" trope...

I think many were expecting a comedy, and it might have even been billed that way.  I enjoyed it, but I didn't get the impression it was meant to be a comedy (even though it had some comedic beats).  For me it seemed like more of a statement on the supposed "messages" of zombie media.
This was quite good, but not the horror movie it was sold as.  Much more of a Thriller...
I was nervous when this started because I didn't know it was going to be in the 'essay' format, but it ended up being quite good.  I'm glad my fears were misplaced.
This was a beautiful long-form music video for Thom Yorke's new album, directed by P.T. Anderson.
I hadn't seen this in forever, never on the big screen, and never this particular version.  It was great.
This is right near my hometown, so when I heard about it I was fascinated, as I was completely ignorant of this topic.  Ford's disregard for these people and this place is mind boggling.
I kickstarted this and noticed it was on Kanopy so I gave it a spin...  It was fascinating on so many levels...
movieTitle: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

movieReview: A friend posted about this movie on Facebook and I watched it as soon as I got home from work.  Still so great.
A quieter film from Tarantino without being all too quiet...  It is a story about old Hollywood but not the story you're expecting when you read a synopsis...
movieTitle: Once Upon a Time ... in Hollywood

movieReview: I was a small-shop snob in my formative years, but I always had respect for Tower even if I rarely made it there.  By the time I settled in Boston they were already on their way out...  But this was a great look at the history of one of the greats.
movieTitle: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records

movieReview: Still wonderful.  Looks great in 4K HDR
This was a well made documentary with the fun gimmick of using children for the reenacted scenes...
Still solid, moves quickly, has some hokey moments but leagues better than Infinity War.
I had wanted to see this for a long time but never got around to it.  Took the opportunity of the anniversary re-release to do so.
We were hunting for something fun to show off our new TV and the in-laws hadn't seen this, so we chose it.

I kickstarted this doc and had been looking forward to it for a long time.  I was finally was able to watch the backer screener and it's great.  Made me want to run thru the entire discography immediately.

This was ok.  I definitely found it funny at times, but overall it relied too much on "OOH LOOK A THIS KID SWEARING" or "OOH LOOK ITS A SEX THING AND THEY ARE IN SIXTH GRADE".  And I am normally not a fan of child actors, and these kids didn't do much to change my opinion.
Finished the book series and wondered what this movie would be like afterwards.  It's still such an amazing turd, and is an embarassment.
This was fun, though knowing the premise from the trailer made the first 3rd of the movie drag a bit.  I suspect not knowing anything would have made it great.
This was a pretty amateurish production, and could have used some editing, but still was a great counterpoint to the "Gygax as Sole Creator" legend.
movieTitle: Secrets of Blackmoor: The True History of Dungeons & Dragons

movieReview: I kind of picked this on a whim, not knowing much about Ronstadt beyond some songs, but knowing how much I enjoy music documentaries.  It was very well made, and Linda has a fascinating career and story.
movieTitle: Linda Ronstadt: The Sound of My Voice

movieReview: This was ok....  I'm not sure why everyone else seems so into this version of Spider-Man yet they seem to leave me vaguely meh...  Way better than the Andrew Garfield versions imo, but still...

This is such a curious movie...  It is not really a remake, even though it touches on some of the same themes and subject matter.  But it is a massively different film from the original.  I'm not certain it actually works, but it was interesting.  It was definitely too long.

I saw this with a live score by the RZA, which was amazing.  The film itself is a well made kung fu film, tho they all tend to be relatively indistinguishable for me.  The transfer was pretty impressive...
A real turd.  A series of events and people that only exist to set up the next thing needed by the plot.

I had been wanting to re-watch this for awhile now, but never got around to it.  While traveling for the McWeaver wedding it came on in the hotel.  At the first commercial break I jumped ship onto the Plex. :). It's still a fun film!

I borrowed this from Harvard as it is about the Fernald Center, which I can see from my office at work.  The place has a fascinating history and while there was plenty of good content in this doc, it's 60m runtime really meant it had to glaze over some things.
This was, charitably, pretty bland.  They could have called it "Powers: The Movie Sequel Product".  It basically is the "Charles Xavier Saving Fallen Mutant" storyline yet again.

I had been wanting to revisit this again for awhile now.  It is such a good movie, and unlike what the Marvel movies have become, it was so nice to have such a small scale story.  The final battle didn't have drones/aliens/demons swarming all around.  Just two robot suits punching each other.
This was bland but fine.  We had a friend over and they wanted to watch it. I think I've only seen THE CONJURING 2 prior to this one...
This was pretty good...  Miike has been a little hit or miss over the years, but this felt like a Guy Ritchie crime ensemble but better.
While I had seen other featurettes/docs on Alien before, this one seemed to go into details I was unfamiliar with.  Quite good (despite a weird, pretentious open).
This was not a movie for everyone.  It really didn't have much to say, but it created a very uncomfortable feeling which I appreciated.
I feared that this would end up diminishing my memory of the show, but if anything it made me want to watch the show again.   Truly enjoyed it.
movieTitle: El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie

movieReview: Recently listened to a podcast about Enron and it made me want to watch this doc again.  Still so good.
movieTitle: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room

movieReview: This was a weeeeird one.  I had heard it was comedic, and while there were comedic moments it definitely wasn't a comedy.  I'm not actually sure WHAT it was...
This has to be the best Exorcist sequel, though it's no great shakes.  Brad Dourif has some great moments in it, and the camerawork is strange and unsettling.
I knew Eugene's comedy, but really didn't know much about his festival nor his family.  This was a nice view into both.
This was forgettable.  Not bad, just not much of anything.
This was way more adorable that you'd expect from the logline.  It was also touching and funny.
Meh.  It was fine, but it was like "Terminator: The Force Awakens But Way More Mediocre".

This was OK, which was way better than I was expecting.  I willfully tried to put THE SHINING out of my mind, as it's one of my favorite films and few directors can be compared to Kubrick...  It felt about 20m too long, and the conclusion in the Overlook was not great (though very impressive from a technical standpoint), but it was an OK horror flick.
This was a solid dramatization of the investigation and creation of the CIA torture report.
This was very good.  It felt a little long, but at 3.5 hours it FELT shorter than many 2 hour films I've seen this year.
Not great.  The things that I didn't like about the first one were dialed up to 11.  The book had the right idea of interleaving the scenes w/ the children and those with the adults.
It was a perfectly acceptable episode of Downton Abbey, but I don't really see what made it a film.
I was expecting more of a thriller, but this was just sad.

This was not good, and I had such high hopes for it.  You take an unlikeable character, make him incompetent, and have him lose at every turn, and why am I even watching this?  And then you make it 130+ minutes and have a ton of non-actors playing parts.
Still fantastic.
movieTitle: Once Upon a Time ... in Hollywood

movieReview: This was a good counterpoint to the Mr. Rogers doc from a few years ago...  Instead of focusing on Mr. Rogers life, it focuses on a moment where he connected with a reporter... I enjoyed it quite a bit, and it made me cry a few times, but it's not necessary.
movieTitle: A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood

movieReview: A nice little profile of Mel Brooks, not your standard bio but instead a collection of moments, not necessarily in order.
Watched in advance of seeing Episode 9.  Still very good.
movieTitle: Star Wars: Episode VIII - The Last Jedi

movieReview: This was kind of a "Viable Star Wars Product" situation.  It was fun, but it was super safe and super overstuffed.  That said, I'll definitely be seeing it again.
movieTitle: Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker

movieReview: Always a classic!
Had to watch the canon for Christmas Eve.
So good.
Hadn't watched this in years, it's still bananas... Definitely MST3K-worthy.
I liked this more on the second viewing...  It still has problems, but it was definitely fun.
movieTitle: Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker

movieReview: I couldn't tell you the last time I saw this movie, but it was almost certainly in the 90s...  It's still surprisingly good!
